Greeks Consider
Rushing Change
Changes in the length and time
of the present rush season are
being considered by the InterFraternity Board, which met last
week to discuss general plans as
proposed by member fraternities.
IFB president Bill Kolomaznik
said that a change will "definitely" be made this year, and will
become effective beginning with
the fall term of next year. He also
said that "the length of the rush
season is the bisic factor" inseason is the basic factor" involved.
He emphasized the "need to
compromise,.a lot among ourselves," before asking for critifor
and
cisms
suggestions
changes from the member fraternities. Ron Nagler of Alpha
Delta Phi proposed a plan whereby there would be no rush rules
at all binding fraternities, though
fraternities would not be allowed
to pledge freshmen until the first
week in May, or sometime near
the end of spring semester.
Nagler said second semester
pledging was better because the
fraternities and freshmen both
"know each other better—it gives
a longer time for the fraternities
and a better position to the freshmen to decide" on the pledging
question.
He also added that second semester /rushing would help cut

CLIMAX in tonight's Barnstormer production, "Petrified Forest."
by DAVE BRANT

JHU To Receive
Moneys, Stocks
Of Black Estate
The Johns Hopkins University
has been named a beneficiary in
the will of the late Harry C.
Black, chairman of the board of
A. S. Abell Company, publishers
of the Sunpapers.
Johns 'Hopkins will benefit in
Black's estate, nominallY estimated "in excess of $2,000,000,"
along with Princeton University
and the Enoch Pratt Free Library.
In the will, filed November 29,
JHU is bequeathed 1300 shares
of stock of the Fidelity-National
Bank and Trust Company and
2500 shares of Fidelity and Deposit Company.
An undisclosed number of
shares of A S. Abell Company
stock was left to a charitable
organization, The A. S. Abell
Company, Inc., with the request
that one-half the dividends of
the •stock for the next four or
five years be given to the JHU.

Homewood Christmas Assembly
To Inaugurate Hungarian Relief
Traditional Christmas carol
singing and an appeal to the
student body to help in the Hungarian relief program will be the
features of the annual Christmas
assembly, to be held Friday, December 14 at 10:00 a.m. in Shriver Hall.
The Dean of Women of Goucher, Miss Elizabeth Geen, will
Speak at the assembly, while the
Goucher and Hopkins Glee Clubs
and the Hopkins Orchestra will
Perform. Community singing will
also take place. Dr. Chester
Wickwire, director of the Hopkins YMCA, will deliver the invocation.
Miss Geen's talk will concern
the Hungarian escapees. Student
Council assembly chairman Bob
Baensch said, "There most likely will be a collection" at the
end of the assembly for the Hungarian Relief program.
Following the example of Yale
University, which collected in a
student rally $1,200 for the Relief program, Baensch and Dan
Tracy will act as co-chairmen
for a Relief Rally

S. C. Sets Regulations
For Student Conduct
Gentleman's Code Commission
Chairman Iry Sekulow met with
representatives of several student
organizations to explain the Student Council's interpretation of
the conduct-controlling resolutions it passed two weeks ago.
Sekulow said that the Student
Council was not trying to hinder
anyone's power or activities, but
that the resolutions were made
in order to prevent incidents such
as the destruction in the ROTC
building after the Senior party
or the run-away pep rally, both
of which occurred last year. He
added that the resolutions were
suggested by Dean Shaffer.
Sekulow said, "In an effort to
make the organizations and student body more aware of their
obligations the Student Council
took under advisement the four
proposed resolutions of the Gentleman's Code Committee.
Approved Resolutions
After considerable discussion
and adjustments the following
are approved resolutions:
"1. No individual or organization should, contrary to accepted standards of gentlemanly conduct, engage in any activity or act which would endanger any other individual
and/or public or private property.
"2. Any Hopkins organization
planning to sponsor an activity
on or off campus should meet
with the Gentleman's Code Committee to mane certain that
proper precautions are being
taken in conducting the activity.
"3. In the event that it is
found from an investigation by
the Student Council that the
sponsoring organization has not
taken proper cautions to discourage ungentlemanly conduct
the Student Council will recommend that action be taken up
to withholding of their funds—
it being an established fact that

the Student Council can declare
an activity inactive.
"4. In the event that it is
found from an investigation by
the Student Council that an individual has admittedly engaged in an act that was contrary to accepted standards of
gentlemanly conduct which endangered another individual and
(or) public or private property,
the Student Council will subject
the individual to:
"a. Payment for any damages
to property belonging either to
public or private individuals that
he caused while engaging in his
ungentlemanly act.
"None of these resolutions, it
should be pointed out, were
adopted with the purpose in mind
to usurp anyone's rights or privileges, but rather to guarantee
high standards of conduct in the
community of the University.
These resolutions, it is hoped,
will guide the behavior among
students on the Campus or at
the location of Campus-sponsored activities.
"To enforce these resolutions
the Student Council will rely on
the moral principles of the community, hoping that these principles are embodied in enough
of the community's members to
guarantee gentlemanly conduct.
It might be added that the Student Council in passing these
resolutions, has in no way provided for a trial panel to try
non-academic violations, because
it is _hoped that Hopkins men
will be able to accept the responsibility of a community of
gentlemen.

Kuznets To Give
Talk In Shriver
Wednesday Night
by MONTE STIFFMAN
Dr. Simon Kuznets, professor
of Political Economy, will deliver the second University Lecture on Wednesday, December
12, at 8:15 p.m. in Shriver Hall
on the topic of "National Income: Its Measure and Its Meaning."
Dr. Kuznets graduated from
the University of Pennsylvania,
and later taught and received
his Ph.D. there. He is a member
of the National Bureau of Economic Research, has served on
the War Production Board from
1942 to 1944, and is the author
of several books on national income.
The University Lecture Series
was set up several years ago by
the University's Group Council.
Speakers are chosen by a vote
of the faculty at large, and an
invitation to deliver a lecture is
considered one of "the highest
honors bestowed by the faculty
upon one of its members," according to the Group Council..
Dr. Kuznet's lecture follows
that of Dr. Strauss, given two
weeks ago, on the "Origin of
Man." Subsequent lectures in the
series will include one on "The
Studies on the Biology of Inflammation" by Dr. Barry Wood,
Jr., vice-president of Johns Hopkins Hospital and University on
March 13; and one by professor
of History Sidney Painter on
"Feudalism in Western Civilization" on April 10. All lectures
are at 8:15 p.m. in Shriver Hall.

Job Interviews
Start This Week
In Levering Hall
Job interviews for seniors and
graduate students began this
week and will run through
March, according to Mr. Lynn
Rogers, head of the University
Placement Bureau.
Approximately 220 business organizations will be represented
on campus to interview seniorand graduate applicants, 50 of
them in December, said Rogers,
adding that the Placement Bureau is also in contact with 400
other firms.
The visiting representatives
will hold interviews in the Placement Bureau offices and in Levering Great Hall. They will also
meet with faculty heads and
members of the various departments.
The interviews, each la.sting
20-30 minutes, will aid the companies in determining the interest and capabilities of the applicants.

who leave the University in February due to academic failure,
and who become subject to '"frustration, heavy drinking and high
pressure to join a fraternity" during their first months at the University.
Nagler finally stated that fraternities would get pledges who
are more aware of fraternity actions under second semseter
rushing because the boys who
want to join fraternities after
delaying their pledging until second semester show a "real desire
to belong to and participate in"
fraternity actions.
Beta Theta Pi backed the plan,
saying their investigation of other
college rush systems showed second semester rushing was preferred to second year rushing,
and that colleges with second
year rushing had found it difficult for fraternities and freshmen, both, and were considering
second semester rushing instead.
Beta also felt it would be "easier
on freshmen" to rush second se-

mester, and not to shorten the
first semester rush time.
Alpha Epsilon Pi backed Nagler's plan on the same grounds
as, Beta. Delta Phi added that "a
longer rush period would get better men, arid would cut out
'Snowing" the freshmen."
A straw vote of the twelve member fraternities indicated that
seven of them were willing to
continue further discussion on the
proposal, while five of them were
not.
The' major objections raised
against the plan were centered
around the financial loss involved. Phi Kappa Psi, Phi Sigma
Delta ("It's financially disastrous, we've got a fraternity house
to fill"), Delta Upsilon ("It's
rough money-wise"), and Delta
Phi (". .. a sel ious money problem"), were against it.
Phi Kappa Psi maintained that
"committments will be made before rushing begins, and you will
have boys running around with
six or seven pledge pins in their
pockets."
Phi Kappa Psi also pointed to
the "extended intensification of

rushing" under the proposal, as
did Phi Gamma Delta, ("It's hard
to keep up the hard rush pace"),
and that freshmen will, "lose interest" in fraternities under a
second term or second year plan.
Alpha Tau Omega and Phi Sigma Delta backed them up on this
point.
Beta Theta Pi said that a longer rush period would "cut competition" and would eliminate
"the need for a six week snow
job," but urged that the no-rushrules idea be modified to incorporate some limitations on fraternity rushing.
Alpha Delta Phi emphasized
the need to "find the middle
road on the rules issue . .. establish flexible rules," and said
that "through the long look (under second semester rushing) fraternities can be honest with the
freshmen."

He puts communications on the go

ESSO

Martin Jepson, E.E., Purdue, '53,
is an Engineer in the Radio and
Special Services Section of Illinois
Bell Telephone Company.
"I help design mobile radiotelephone systems," says Martin. "We
have a wide variety of customers,
including trucking firms, railroads
and marine traffic of all kinds. Many
businessmen, too, want these systems
for their private cars. Each customer
has his own communications problems, and these are a constant and
stimulating engineering challenge.
"Another part of my job is to help
set up facilities for conventions,

ESSO STANDARD OIL COMPANY
RESEARCH AND ENGINEERING COMPANY

sports events and tile like. Last summer's Democratic National Convention, for instance, used enough
circuits and facilities to serve a small
city. There were special circuits for
broadcasting, teletypewriters, the
press, and for inside communications. It was our job to set those
facilities up and keep them operating.
"The increase in demand for telephone and related services is phenomenal. It's this growth that's
creating real career opportunities in
the telephone business. Add to this
the fact that it's a stable business,
and you've really got something!"

Martin Jepson is one of many young men who
are finding interesting careers in Bell Telephone Companies, and also in Bell Telephone
Laboratories, Western Electric and Sandia Corporation. See your placement officer for more
information about Bell System Companies.

The Collegiate Nutshell
The collegiate nutshell provides the protection of
isolation from the troubles of the outer world. We have
petty politics and transient academic woes to distract
US from deeper problems. By avoiding or being unable to
perceive any unpleasantness, we can convince ourselves
all's right with the world. He who would break this illusion is most unwelcome.
Among a populace whose greatest emotions are
evinced by the perpetual Student Council and SAC
harangues, and by inter-fraternity pledging competition,
it is difficult to negate the distractions and to concentrate
on more important and more significant problems. Indeed
the consideration of University problems is frowned upon,
and on the international level is impossible.
We are, for instance, incapable of viewing the Hungarian revolution as being more than a shame. Like all
shames it has its resulting obligation. Just as there are
poor boxes for the poor, there are also collections for the
Hungarians. LuckilY, we Sigh internally, we aren't forced
to come in contact with them. After all that fighting, the
Hungarians are probably neither well-dressed nor cleanshaven.
Thus when some thousands of Hungarians are killed
in a- hopeless revolt against an overwhelniing oppression,
we can view with a certain latent sadism the pictures
of the aftermath, and we can get a satisfaction resembling the one produced by Orwell's two-minute hate, whenwe see a red star being torn from its moorings. Some of
us can even , get excited enough to sign petitions demanding the country's rehabilitation. But when the petitions
are ignored and the "good" side does nOt triumph after a
respectable time, as happens in the most satisfying movies,
novels, and television shows, and the reports of the rout
of the rebels linger in the news for weeks, we turn our
spare moments to more satisfying diversions. We attempt
to preserve our bland security without any undue thought
or concern.
We can't understand the emotions felt by the Hungarians. We've never felt them, and in our be-tweeded
and button-down world, we probably never will.
Thus; the well-meant attempt to secure permission
to collect money for the Hungarians at next Friday's
Christmas Assembly has been met with protests that
there is not enough time; that songs of good will and
peace on earth will consume the entire hour. Yet, in its
proper place, a collection will be taken. There will be a.
rally that weekend which we may attend, cheer, and if
we are deeply enough moved, we may contribute our dollars. Or we may go to the movies that night, instead.

Moneys, Stocks
Of Black Estate
The Johns Hopkins University
has been named a beneficiary in
the will of the late Harry C.
Black, chairman of the board of
A. S. Abell Company, publishers
of the Sunpapers.
Johns 'Hopkins will benefit in
Black's estate, nominallY estimated "in excess of $2,000,000,"
along with Princeton University
and the Enoch Pratt Free Library.
In the will, filed November 29,
JHU is bequeathed 1300 shares
of stock of the Fidelity-National
Bank and Trust Company and
2500 shares of Fidelity and Deposit Company.
An undisclosed number of
shares of A S. Abell Company
stock was left to a charitable
organization, The A. S. Abell
Company, Inc., with the request
that one-half the dividends of
the •stock for the next four or
five years be given to the JHU.

S. C. Sets Regulations
For Student Conduct
Gentleman's Code Commission
Chairman Iry Sekulow met with
representatives of several student
organizations to explain the Student Council's interpretation of
the conduct-controlling resolutions it passed two weeks ago.
Sekulow said that the Student
Council was not trying to hinder
anyone's power or activities, but
that the resolutions were made
in order to prevent incidents such
as the destruction in the ROTC
building after the Senior party
or the run-away pep rally, both
of which occurred last year. He
added that the resolutions were
suggested by Dean Shaffer.
Sekulow said, "In an effort to
make the organizations and student body more aware of their
obligations the Student Council
took under advisement the four
proposed resolutions of the Gentleman's Code Committee.
Approved Resolutions
After considerable discussion
and adjustments the following
are approved resolutions:
"1. No individual or organization should, contrary to accepted standards of gentlemanly conduct, engage in any activity or act which would endanger any other individual
and/or public or private property.
"2. Any Hopkins organization
planning to sponsor an activity
on or off campus should meet
with the Gentleman's Code Committee to mane certain that
proper precautions are being
taken in conducting the activity.
"3. In the event that it is
found from an investigation by
the Student Council that the
sponsoring organization has not
taken proper cautions to discourage ungentlemanly conduct
the Student Council will recommend that action be taken up
to withholding of their funds—
it being an established fact that

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, DEC. 7, 1956

the Student Council can declare
an activity inactive.
"4. In the event that it is
found from an investigation by
the Student Council that an individual has admittedly engaged in an act that was contrary to accepted standards of
gentlemanly conduct which endangered another individual and
(or) public or private property,
the Student Council will subject
the individual to:
"a. Payment for any damages
to property belonging either to
public or private individuals that
he caused while engaging in his
ungentlemanly act.
"None of these resolutions, it
should be pointed out, were
adopted with the purpose in mind
to usurp anyone's rights or privileges, but rather to guarantee
high standards of conduct in the
community of the University.
These resolutions, it is hoped,
will guide the behavior among
students on the Campus or at
the location of Campus-sponsored activities.
"To enforce these resolutions
the Student Council will rely on
the moral principles of the community, hoping that these principles are embodied in enough
of the community's members to
guarantee gentlemanly conduct.
It might be added that the Student Council in passing these
resolutions, has in no way provided for a trial panel to try
non-academic violations, because
it is _hoped that Hopkins men
will be able to accept the responsibility of a community of
gentlemen.

Kuznets To Give
Talk In Shriver
Wednesday Night
by MONTE STIFFMAN
Dr. Simon Kuznets, professor
of Political Economy, will deliver the second University Lecture on Wednesday, December
12, at 8:15 p.m. in Shriver Hall
on the topic of "National Income: Its Measure and Its Meaning."
Dr. Kuznets graduated from
the University of Pennsylvania,
and later taught and received
his Ph.D. there. He is a member
of the National Bureau of Economic Research, has served on
the War Production Board from
1942 to 1944, and is the author
of several books on national income.
The University Lecture Series
was set up several years ago by
the University's Group Council.
Speakers are chosen by a vote
of the faculty at large, and an
invitation to deliver a lecture is
considered one of "the highest
honors bestowed by the faculty
upon one of its members," according to the Group Council..
Dr. Kuznet's lecture follows
that of Dr. Strauss, given two
weeks ago, on the "Origin of
Man." Subsequent lectures in the
series will include one on "The
Studies on the Biology of Inflammation" by Dr. Barry Wood,
Jr., vice-president of Johns Hopkins Hospital and University on
March 13; and one by professor
of History Sidney Painter on
"Feudalism in Western Civilization" on April 10. All lectures
are at 8:15 p.m. in Shriver Hall.

down the number of freshmen

are more aware of fraternity actions under second semseter
rushing because the boys who
want to join fraternities after

to belong to and participate in"

Beta Theta Pi backed the plan,
saying their investigation of other
college rush systems showed second semester rushing was preferred to second year rushing,
and that colleges with second
year rushing had found it difficult for fraternities and freshmen, both, and were considering
second semester rushing instead.
Beta also felt it would be "easier
on freshmen" to rush second se-

mester, and not to shorten the
first semester rush time.
Alpha Epsilon Pi backed Nagler's plan on the same grounds
as, Beta. Delta Phi added that "a
longer rush period would get better men, arid would cut out
'Snowing" the freshmen."
A straw vote of the twelve member fraternities indicated that
seven of them were willing to
continue further discussion on the
proposal, while five of them were
not.
The' major objections raised
against the plan were centered
around the financial loss involved. Phi Kappa Psi, Phi Sigma
Delta ("It's financially disastrous, we've got a fraternity house
to fill"), Delta Upsilon ("It's
rough money-wise"), and Delta
Phi (". .. a sel ious money problem"), were against it.
Phi Kappa Psi maintained that
"committments will be made before rushing begins, and you will
have boys running around with
six or seven pledge pins in their
pockets."
Phi Kappa Psi also pointed to
the "extended intensification of

rushing" under the proposal, as
did Phi Gamma Delta, ("It's hard
to keep up the hard rush pace"),
and that freshmen will, "lose interest" in fraternities under a
second term or second year plan.
Alpha Tau Omega and Phi Sigma Delta backed them up on this
point.
Beta Theta Pi said that a longer rush period would "cut competition" and would eliminate
"the need for a six week snow
job," but urged that the no-rushrules idea be modified to incorporate some limitations on fraternity rushing.
Alpha Delta Phi emphasized
the need to "find the middle
road on the rules issue . .. establish flexible rules," and said
that "through the long look (under second semester rushing) fraternities can be honest with the
freshmen."

He puts communications on the go

ESSO

Martin Jepson, E.E., Purdue, '53,
is an Engineer in the Radio and
Special Services Section of Illinois
Bell Telephone Company.
"I help design mobile radiotelephone systems," says Martin. "We
have a wide variety of customers,
including trucking firms, railroads
and marine traffic of all kinds. Many
businessmen, too, want these systems
for their private cars. Each customer
has his own communications problems, and these are a constant and
stimulating engineering challenge.
"Another part of my job is to help
set up facilities for conventions,

ESSO STANDARD OIL COMPANY
RESEARCH AND ENGINEERING COMPANY

sports events and tile like. Last summer's Democratic National Convention, for instance, used enough
circuits and facilities to serve a small
city. There were special circuits for
broadcasting, teletypewriters, the
press, and for inside communications. It was our job to set those
facilities up and keep them operating.
"The increase in demand for telephone and related services is phenomenal. It's this growth that's
creating real career opportunities in
the telephone business. Add to this
the fact that it's a stable business,
and you've really got something!"

Martin Jepson is one of many young men who

The Collegiate Nutshell
The collegiate nutshell provides the protection of
isolation from the troubles of the outer world. We have
petty politics and transient academic woes to distract
US from deeper problems. By avoiding or being unable to
perceive any unpleasantness, we can convince ourselves
all's right with the world. He who would break this illusion is most unwelcome.
Among a populace whose greatest emotions are
evinced by the perpetual Student Council and SAC
harangues, and by inter-fraternity pledging competition,
it is difficult to negate the distractions and to concentrate
on more important and more significant problems. Indeed
the consideration of University problems is frowned upon,
and on the international level is impossible.
We are, for instance, incapable of viewing the Hungarian revolution as being more than a shame. Like all
shames it has its resulting obligation. Just as there are
poor boxes for the poor, there are also collections for the
Hungarians. LuckilY, we Sigh internally, we aren't forced
to come in contact with them. After all that fighting, the
Hungarians are probably neither well-dressed nor cleanshaven.
Thus when some thousands of Hungarians are killed
in a- hopeless revolt against an overwhelniing oppression,
we can view with a certain latent sadism the pictures
of the aftermath, and we can get a satisfaction resembling the one produced by Orwell's two-minute hate, whenwe see a red star being torn from its moorings. Some of
us can even , get excited enough to sign petitions demanding the country's rehabilitation. But when the petitions
are ignored and the "good" side does nOt triumph after a
respectable time, as happens in the most satisfying movies,
novels, and television shows, and the reports of the rout
of the rebels linger in the news for weeks, we turn our
spare moments to more satisfying diversions. We attempt
to preserve our bland security without any undue thought
or concern.
We can't understand the emotions felt by the Hungarians. We've never felt them, and in our be-tweeded
and button-down world, we probably never will.
Thus; the well-meant attempt to secure permission
to collect money for the Hungarians at next Friday's
Christmas Assembly has been met with protests that
there is not enough time; that songs of good will and
peace on earth will consume the entire hour. Yet, in its
proper place, a collection will be taken. There will be a.
rally that weekend which we may attend, cheer, and if
we are deeply enough moved, we may contribute our dollars. Or we may go to the movies that night, instead.
